required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Vaporous Hyperoxia Therapy (VHT) in the Treatment of Chronic Diabetic Foot Ulcers
clinical_study.official_title: Treating Non-healing Foot Wounds With Vaporous Hyperoxia Therapy as an Adjunct to Standard Wound Care

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of Vaporous Hyperoxia Therapy (VHT) for the treatment of Diabetic Foot Ulcers.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of Vaporous Hyperoxia Therapy (VHT) for the treatment of Diabetic Foot Ulcers. VHT treatments will be provided as an adjunct to standard wound care. Subjects will receive VHT treatments until wound closure, or for the treatment period of 20 weeks.

primary_outcome.description: The percentage of subjects that achieved complete wound closure by week 20, where wound closure is defined by complete re-epithelialization without drainage

secondary_outcome.description: The percentage of subjects that achieved complete wound closure by week 12, where wound closure is defined by complete re-epithelialization without drainage
Time to percent reduction in volume (length x width x depth) from baseline

arm_group.description: Patients will be treated with VHT for 55 minutes at a minimum frequency of 2 times per week

intervention.description: 55 minutes of treatment, 2 times per week

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diabetic foot wound, graded by the Wagner Scale as a 1,2 or 3
- Wound has resisted healing with standard wound care for at least 6 weeks
- No symptoms of sepsis
- Able to maintain reasonable nutrition and hydration
- Able to maintain adequate home care between treatment visits
- Able to understand and follow basic wound care instructions, or has caregiver who can assist
Exclusion Criteria:
- Skin wounds cancer/neoplastic etiology
- Wounds that involve osteomyelitis or tendon involvement
- Diagnosis of methicillin resistant staph aureus by wound swab
- Acute skin conditions
- Surgery within 30 days of study onset
- Wounds where the end cannot be probed
- Participation in another clinical trial within 120 days prior to study onset
- Non-compliant patients
- Pregnancy
- Presence of co-morbid conditions that in the physician's opinion exclude the individual from the study

overall_official.affiliation: Rocky Mountain Foot and Ankle Center

facility.name: Rock Canyon Foot and Ankle Clinic
Rocky Mountain Foot and Ankle Center
